channel.title: Fashion – SUBCULTURED Magazine
channel.description: A fashion, culture, art and music publication, written by students about students.

item.title: The Oscar Outfits That Defined The 2010’s
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
It is that time of year…the Academy Awards are on the horizon once again and all eyes will be on the slew of stars vying for the coveted trophies. And of course most of us this February will be on tenterhooks in anticipation of the red carpet show stoppers! A new decade will bring an […]

The post The Oscar Outfits That Defined The 2010’s appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
It is that time of year…the Academy Awards are on the horizon once again and all eyes will be on the slew of stars vying for the coveted trophies. And of course most of us this February will be on tenterhooks in anticipation of the red carpet show stoppers! A new decade will bring an array of fresh trends, but what looks hold a rightful place in award ceremony fashion history? Here you have it SUBCULTURED’s review of the most distinguished Oscar ensembles from the last ten years…

10. Jennifer Lawrence, 2011

Jennifer Lawrence was just 20 years old when she attended her first Academy Awards in 2011 and to mark the occasion, she wore a simple, form-fitting red Calvin Klein gown. The simplicity of the style made it an undeniable knock-out.

Ian West/PA Images via Getty Images

9. Mila Kunis, 2011

Mila Kunis’ 2011 Elie Saab gown is hard to forget. The stunning sheer panels and the flowing lace made the gown glamourous and pre-Raphaelite. Kunis looked like she’d be more at home in a 15th century painting!

via PA

8. Nicole Kidman, 2018

A giant bow on the front of her vivid cobalt Armani gown made Nicole Kidman the centre of attention at the 2018 Academy Awards. The high slit up on the skirt injected a cheeky stroke of glamour.

Dan MacMedan via WireImage

7. Gemma Chan, 2019 

Gemma Chan’s stunning pink taffeta Valentino gown stole all of our hearts. Aside from being elegant and glamourous, the innovative dress also had pockets! Chan has her priorities straight!

Richard Shotwell/Invision/AP

6. Cate Blanchett, 2011

The delicate detail on Cate Blanchtt’s 2011 Givenchy gown remains unmatched. Blanchett told InStyle Magazine that the “architectural” style of the dress drew her to it and that the breast plate was fabricated completely in elastic to allow the beautiful beading.

via Viste La Calle

5. Meryl Streep, 2012

Meryl Streep’s stunning gold Lanvin dress is our halfway winner. Streep is often not particularly daring with her red carpet looks, often preferring understated styles. However, she pushed the boat out in 2012 and wore a beautiful fitted sparkling gold dress, proving that Hollywood glamour is timeless!

Rick Rowell/Walt Disney Television via Getty Images

4. Zoe Saldana, 2010 

At the first Academy Awards of the decade, Zoe Saldana wowed in a beautiful Givenchy ombré gown. The bodice was covered in glitter and the skirt turned from pale silk to deep purple tulle. Saldana is never one to play it safe, and for that, we are glad!

Brian To/WireImage

3. Billy Porter, 2019

Last year, Billy Porter wore the most daring outfit a man has ever worn on the Oscar red carpet, and it was incredible. Porter’s Christian Siriano tuxedo gown pushed the boundaries for male red carpet fashion and left us all dying for more! Porter said this about his beautiful gown: “actors are afraid to play, because if they show up as something outside of the status quo, they might be received as feminine, and, as a result, they won’t get that masculine job, that superhero job.” We salute you, Billy.

Richard Shotwell/Invision/AP

2. Angelina Jolie, 2012

Angelina Jolie’s 2012 Versace black gown is infamous in Academy Award fashion history. The high slit in the dress allowed Jolie to stick her leg out on her right side, which was quickly noticed by internet creatives who promptly skyrocketed the moment into meme territory. Jolie told People Magazine “I wore the more comfortable dress, which was that one. And I think I was just so comfortable that…” The rest is red carpet history!

Ethan Miller/Getty Images

1. Lupita Nyong’o, 2014

Earning first place is Lupita Nyong’o’s beautiful custom made Prada gown. The Grecian style is simple but elegant, with its charm lying in its ethereal powder blue hue. Nyong’o chose the dress because “it’s a blue that reminds me of Nairobi,” her hometown in Kenya. The simplicity and sentimental nudge to Nyong’o’s origins make this wonderful piece more than just a pretty frock. Let’s see if anyone can top this masterpiece in the years to come!

Jordan Strauss/Invision/AP

Don’t miss it! The Oscars will take place on Sunday the 9th of February 2020.

Text by Beth Roberts

The post The Oscar Outfits That Defined The 2010’s appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: Big-name Fashion Brands And “Green Washing”
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
Are industry giants guilty of not living up to their claims of sustainability? The idea of going “green” is permeating every modern market. With the textile industry being the second highest polluting industry on Earth, the word “sustainability” finds itself increasingly associated with the world of fashion. It was a recurring theme throughout London and […]

The post Big-name Fashion Brands And “Green Washing” appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Are industry giants guilty of not living up to their claims of sustainability?

The idea of going “green” is permeating every modern market. With the textile industry being the second highest polluting industry on Earth, the word “sustainability” finds itself increasingly associated with the world of fashion. It was a recurring theme throughout London and Paris fashion weeks alike, and even fast-fashion giants such as H&M and Zara have introduced claims on sustainability.

H&M’s introduction of a Conscious range in 2018 commenced their new sustainable model, including a clothes recycling programme. However, Conscious only accounts for 5% of their total clothing output. Ann Gedda, the Head of Sustainability at H&M has said, “Big change requires bold actions and the courage to aim high”, but just how big of a change is 5%?

Alongside H&M, Zara has also made some bold claims. They have stated that by 2025, 100% of their clothing will be “more sustainable”, organic, or recycled.

The problem is that by itself, the word “sustainable” doesn’t mean anything. Big-name brands constantly throw around terms such as “green”, “eco-friendly”, and “responsibly-made”, that looks increasingly more like band-wagoning. Are corporations making genuine changes or simply making hollow statements out of societal obligation?

The problem is, the sheer vagueness of such terminology allows companies to cut corners in environmental preservation and still pander to trusting climate-conscious shoppers. The use of such words is not effectively regulated by governments on any national or international level. They are non-quantifiable adjectives that many companies see as free game, in or out of the fashion industry.  For example, the word “organic” is linked to sustainability, however, it is government mandated with a number of legal qualifiers necessary for a product to be described as such.

In fact, the word “sustainable” itself has no concrete legal definition. There are no strict legal requirements that come behind the use of the word, and no particular qualification process behind a company being able to use it. The United Kingdom Government defines “sustainability” in the 2011 policy paper Mainstreaming sustainable development: the government’s vision and what this means in practice, as the following: “The state towards which the UK Government’s vision for sustainable development aspires”.

Essentially, a meaningless phrase. Until such a time that law-makers standardise sustainability, the word will be continued to be abused by brands. This process is called greenwashing. Greenpeace’s 1999 publication “The Book of Greenwash” outlines the ways in which corporations are able to circumnavigate the United Nation’s rules on environmental impact, whilst still claiming “sustainability” and lying to the very consumers that allow them to exist.

The issue is, the entire fast-fashion business model of short sighted focus on volume, can never be built to last. The obsession with new trends on a seasonal basis allows companies choose profit margin over ethics, time after time. Even if the constant use of toxic dyes, non-recyclable fibres, animal products, copious amounts of water, overall poor quality, and worldwide shipping were all addressed, the sheer production volume and wastage rates alone produce immeasurable quantities of CO2.

Naturally, in a capitalist, ultimately materialistic society, it is impossible to exist without an environmental impact. As consumers, we cannot demand perfection of brands, but we should at least be aware of what we are actually supporting. Your next autumn outfit doesn’t need to come at the cost of supporting unethical practice.

There are a number of red flags we can use to recognise greenwashing…

  • Brands that have a conscious collection rather than the whole line. ASOS is a prime example of this with their Sustainable Edit, as well as Urban Outfitters, and Far Fetch.
  • Large corporation brands. Size does matter it seems, the larger the company, the harder it is for them to implement sustainability throughout their range. It is also easier for them to avert environmental accountability through large donations as a form of corporate purging.
  • Trend-led branding at a rapid turnover rate. In general, the Instagram-based culture of unwearable fashion for the sake of photographs is toxic for long term sustainability. 
  • The name of the brand contains a greenwashing term. Needless to say, this is the primary indicator of a brand using sustainability as a marketing gimmick.
  • Next day shipping. Overnight shipping encourages the culture of never wearing the same outfit twice, as well as expending a huge carbon footprint.  

In the words of Coco Chanel, “fashion comes and goes, style goes on forever forever”. We need to start viewing our wardrobe as a collection of investments, and not just expendable objects to discard when we grow tired of them. Buying higher quality, second hand, or from the countless truly sustainable brands available such as Patagonia, Reformation, People Tree, Boden etc., are measures we can all take to make a difference and move towards making fashion truly sustainable.

Text by Tarryn Burrows
Picture research by Anna Irina; featured image via Pinterest.

The post Big-name Fashion Brands And “Green Washing” appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: 3 Wardrobe Must-Haves For This Season
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
September is almost over! That means the start of a new academic year is on the horizon, and the autumn leaves will soon begin falling. It is almost the time of chai latte drinking, cosy jumper wearing and library study sessions. We couldn’t be more excited to start dressing for the changing seasons! Autumn is […]

The post 3 Wardrobe Must-Haves For This Season appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
September is almost over! That means the start of a new academic year is on the horizon, and the autumn leaves will soon begin falling.

It is almost the time of chai latte drinking, cosy jumper wearing and library study sessions. We couldn’t be more excited to start dressing for the changing seasons! Autumn is the best time of the year to invest in some key pieces for your everyday apparel that will see you through the colder months.

Student life may keep you on a tight budget, but we’ve chosen three wardrobe essentials for A/W19, that won’t break the bank. So, whether it’s your first year fresher attire or final year basics, SUBCULTURED have got you covered on what statement pieces you should start the year with.

The Oversized Coat

Oversized coats are not only great at keeping you warm, they can be bold fashion moves. Puffer coats are still our go-to style for chillier weather as they’re practical and on trend. Puffers are great at hiding all manner of sins, and can make an outfit seem put together when you’ve made minimum effort. They also look great paired with trainers, straight-leg jeans and smart trousers. URBAN OUTFITTERS and Cheap Monday offer a great selection of puffer jackets in lots of vivid colours and different lengths.

If puffer jackets aren’t your thing, you can opt for a more structured style and invest in a trench coat. Trench coats are a great way of making an outfit look more formal and look great when styled with sportswear. Coats with neutral tones are massively on trend for this A/W19. Zara and Topshop have a wide selection of camel and beige coloured trenches.

Bold Chunky Trainers

Chunky trainers have been a huge trend for a few seasons. Balenciaga lead the designer market, whilst Nike have dominated the highstreets. Chunky trainers are a simple way to make your outfit effortlessly urban and we love styling them with suits or skirts. Chunky trainers are a versatile shoe as they complement more minimal, structured outfits like blazers and smart trousers, but can also complement more grungy and laid-back looks. Get your hands on a pair of Nike’s Tekno or Adidas’ Magmur Runner to feel on trend during first semester.

Stand-out Staple Bags

A staple bag plays a vital role in university life. Having a comfortable bag that you can take to lectures as well as trips to town, means you can stay fashionable whilst keeping your belongings safe. It’s important to buy a bag that can fit all your essential possessions, alongside your laptop and folders. We think The North Face and Dickies are a good investment although slightly pricier, they have a range of sturdy rucksacks that will see you through your uni years and beyond!

However, rucksacks aren’t your only option. ASOS do a lot of affordable tote bags in a range of colours. Tote bags look great with any outfit, and are easy to fit a lot of things in.

Text by Natalie Carter
Picture research by Juliéy Pham; featured image from businessinsider.com.

The post 3 Wardrobe Must-Haves For This Season appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: Students In The Fight Against “Fast Fashion”
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
Charity shopping, second-hand selling, and donating; what can I do in Guildford to help slow down the freight train that is the fast fashion industry? And can I really look good while doing it? The phrase “fast fashion” has been thrown around with increasing frequency over the last few years, but what does it really […]

The post Students In The Fight Against “Fast Fashion” appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Charity shopping, second-hand selling, and donating; what can I do in Guildford to help slow down the freight train that is the fast fashion industry? And can I really look good while doing it?

The phrase “fast fashion” has been thrown around with increasing frequency over the last few years, but what does it really mean? Apparently, the term was originally coined to describe the speedy migration of catwalk/celebrity trends to high-street retailers, with popular high-street brands such as Zara, Urban Outfitters, and H&M all promoting themselves as “fast fashion” labels. Recently, however, the term has evolved into a criticism of the very industry it was used to promote. To keep the costs down and the turnaround quick, the use of plastic-based materials, factory production, and in some cases, sweatshops, have become the norm to fuel our endless consumption.

To put things in perspective, 80 billion items of clothing are consumed worldwide each year. In 2019, we are far less likely to hold on to our old clothes than we were 10 years ago, resulting in a whopping £140 million of used, but wearable clothes being sent to landfill every year in the UK alone. To make matters worse, the fast fashion industry perpetuates itself by making clothing that aren’t made to last. Cheap materials and processes mean that our clothes are wearing out more quickly, forcing us to buy more frequently and increasing the masses of clothing sent to landfill every year.

So … what can we do to help? SUBCULTURED have some top tips for avoiding fast fashion in Guildford, as well as presenting to you six different outfits that showcase my personal favourite sustainable pieces, in a bid to convince you that a quick trip to The Friary isn’t always the best option.

This adorable outfit (minus the bag) is entirely second hand. Dungarees are a brilliantly versatile piece that can found super easily in charity or vintage shops. You can dress them up with a button-down shirt like I have here for cute, summery work-wear – or down with your favourite oversized t-shirt for a casual, 90s inspired look.

Don’t get me wrong, I’m not saying that buying or donating a few items to your local charity shop is going to immediately solve the problem that fast fashion poses, but beginning to build up a culture of second-hand shoppers will not only save resources, but also represent a massive step in forcing the fast fashion industry to reconsider their business model.

There are multiple routes to take in terms of finding clothing second hand which I am going to divide into three categories:
1. Charity Shopping
2. Online Shopping
3. Vintage Shopping

Charity Shopping

The reason I come to charity shopping first is because I know that a lot of young people are sceptical about the idea. For a long time, the charity shop was associated with grandparents and eccentrics. However, our humble Oxfams are drawing increasing crowds of environment and style conscious young people every day. The trick to charity shopping is to have patience and an open mind. A lot of people find it intimidating – the fact that there’s only one of every item, the sometimes out-dated pieces, the slightly dusty smell – but that feeling you get when you pick up an absolute gem from the rack of grandma sweaters and check the price tag (£1.99!!) is, in itself, priceless.

The point I wanted to prove with this outfit is that second hand stuff doesn’t have to be casual. I dressed up my outfit here with some sunglasses and platforms I already had in my wardrobe to create a look that I’d definitely wear on a night out.

In Guildford, there are tonnes of charity shops to check out that stock a range of items from clothing, shoes and accessories to books, music, and homewear.

You’ll need to begin at Phoenix Court to check out the Phyllis Tuckwell Hospice store.

Then, head back into White Lion Walk on North Street to visit the newly refurbished British Heart Foundation, located on the ground floor.

After that, head out across the High Street and take a trip down Quarry Street, stopping at Oxfam and the second Phyllis Tuckwell store.

Head back on yourself to take a stroll up Guildford High Street (who said shopping wasn’t valid exercise?) and dip into Save the Children which is nestled in Jeffrey’s Passage.

Continue up the high street to drop in at the Oxfam book store, Cancer Research UK, and end up at our final Oxfam, located just next to Pizza Express (phew!). After this trip (which weighs in at almost bang on 1 kilometre) you’ll at least have burned a few calories.

Since we’re right in the middle of Festival Season I thought it would be a waste not to include a fest-themed fit. For this outfit I focused on a balance between style and comfort to create a look that will stand out, but also be practical for a long day of dancing, camping, and exploring. 

Charity shopping has endless benefits, with positive implications for both the environment and the varied causes that your money is going towards. However, donating your unwanted items is also a great way to give new life to old clothes, accessories, books, and homewear, sparing them the fate of landfill. Donating is as easy as bringing a bag of items into your local store, but lots of charities also offer collection services from home, school, or work – information on which can be found here.

Online Shopping

If trekking around charity shops doesn’t fit your schedule (or just gives you a headache) online second-hand shopping has faced a massive boom in the last few years. A big increase in its popularity can be attributed to the introduction of Depop – a buying and selling app with an Instagram-like interface that has been a massive hit amongst young people.

Depop is incredibly easy to use as both a buyer and a seller, with a detailed ‘search’ mechanism with tonnes of filters, promoted sellers based on your interests, and a review system so that you know if you can really trust who you’re buying from.

Oxfam have even stepped on the trend with the creation of their own Depop account (@OxfamOnline), so that you can browse to your heart’s content without having to leave the comfort of your home.

As if we need any more options, many charity shops and vintage outlets also now have their own online shops – either independently or through the popular selling forum, Ebay – which will be linked at the end of this article.

Not to be forgotten, the student favourite ASOS also have taken a step into more sustainable fashion through the creation of ASOS Marketplace. Although it’s not guaranteed that 100% of the brands represented there are ethical and sustainable, a few that are promoting various forms of sustainability can be found here. Thanks ASOS!

If you can’t find anything you want to order, selling online is a great way to clear out your wardrobe and provide your unwanted items a new home that isn’t a landfill site. Plus, it’s a fairly easy way to make cash which can be a lifesaver for a busy (and broke) student.

When a lot of people think retro clothing, they tend to think 70s or 80s, but – nowadays – there are plenty of 90s and Y2K items in second hand stores. Since these styles are making a big comeback in mainstream fashion, I thought I’d showcase just a few of the 90s-inspired bits and pieces I’ve picked up recently to create this look.

Vintage Shopping

So, what exactly is “vintage”? According to the dictionary, the term “vintage” denotes “something from the past of high quality.” Luckily for us, vintage items have faced a massive mainstream popularity spike in recent years, with pre-loved stores such as To Be Worn Again, Beyond Retro, and Rokit paving the way. All of these stores stock tonnes of rare and beautiful second-hand pieces that will be sure to make you stand out from the crowd.

To make life even easier, the University of Surrey even hold their own vintage shopping events in collaboration with Goldrush Vintage and Yellow Jelly. Multiple times a year, Rubix is transformed into a marketplace full of quality second hand clothing from dresses and dungarees to jumpers and jeans. This is a must-see event for stylish students, so make sure to look out for the event on Facebook.

Another fun event to attend is the kilo sale up at Guildford Cathedral. Guildford has been a stop on Preloved Vintage Wholesale’s kilo sale tour for many years, so head up there, fill a bag, weigh it in and pay £15 per kilo of second hand gems! Find info and tour dates here!

For this look my main focus was wear-ability. I wanted to create a more toned-down look, inspired by streetwear, which you could easily wear to Uni or on a day out. Using small, thrifted accessories like chains, jewellery, and sunglasses can really make something as simple as jean shorts and a t-shirt look more unique and put-together. A really extra photo shoot on a tennis court also helps.

If you have a day off and fancy a trip out of town, both London and Brighton are brilliant second-hand locations. With Waterloo only 36 minutes away by train and Brighton a slightly more adventurous 1 hour 30, the shopping alone is a brilliant excuse to pay a visit. From Waterloo, be sure to take the Northern Line to Camden Town to explore the wealth of vintage shops packed full of unique fashion and curiosities. In addition, with plenty of quirky food options to be found at venues like The Cheese Bar and Rudy’s Dirty Vegan Diner, you can make a proper day of it. Find a list of London’s “best thrift stores” here, and “best charity shops” here.

In Brighton, head down to the North Laine (only a two minute walk from Brighton Station) to be in second-hand heaven. Get lost in Snooper’s Paradise, browse the rails in To Be Worn Again, and check out Dirty Harry for some filthy deals. The North Laine is also full of eateries galore, my personal favourites being the tasty We Heart Falafel; the restaurant famous for its Korean Bimibap, Namul; and the Instagram-worthy Balcony Café. If all that wasn’t enough, Brighton is also home to a ridiculous number of charity shops, the list of which have been narrowed down to a top ten here.

For my final outfit I was desperate to showcase how ridiculously cheap you can find quality items when shopping second-hand. This oversized wool cardigan and gorgeous satin dress were only £1 each at Brighton’s Shabitat, and yet they come together to create an adorably classy look.

I know, avoiding big fast fashion brands is hard – after all, they make it so easy, which I guess is sort of the point. I’m not saying that I have an entire wardrobe full of second hand clothing made out of sustainable materials … because I don’t. I love a Topshop sale from time to time, and I’m constantly being lured in by the sweet call of student discount at Urban Outfitters. However, if you can make an effort, no matter how small, to buy, sell, or donate your items second-hand, that’s a step, and with all the options as a student in Guildford – why wouldn’t you?

Online Vintage Outlets:
To Be Worn Again: https://tobewornagain.co.uk/
Beyond Retro: https://www.beyondretro.com/
Rokit: https://www.rokit.co.uk/
Retro Daisy: https://www.retrodaisy.com/

Online Charity Shops:
British Red Cross: https://www.ebay.co.uk/str/britishredcross
Cancer Research UK: https://www.cancerresearchuk.org/get-involved/ways-to-shop
The Children’s Society: https://www.childrenssociety.org.uk/our-shops
Isabel Hospice: https://www.isabelhospice.org.uk/support-us/shop/shop-online
Marie Curie: https://shop.mariecurie.org.uk/
Oxfam: https://www.oxfam.org.uk/shop
Rowcroft Hospice: https://www.rowcrofthospice.org.uk/get-involved/shops/shop-online-us/
Sense: https://www.sense.org.uk/support-us/shop/shop-online/
Sue Ryder: https://www.sueryder.org/support-us/shop-with-us

Text by Flo Wadey (@_flo_wer)
In-text images by Phoebe Wadey (@phee.beee)
Picture research by Anna Irina
Featured image via giveme-5.org.

The post Students In The Fight Against “Fast Fashion” appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: The Workwear Edit – Placement Year Style Essentials
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
It’s that time of year. It’s been a tiring few months of sending off CV after CV, nervously waiting for Skype interviews or travelling across the country for assessment centres. As if the pressures of exams and assignments weren’t stressful enough, some of us have decided to add an extra strain by deciding to do […]

The post The Workwear Edit – Placement Year Style Essentials appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
It’s that time of year. It’s been a tiring few months of sending off CV after CV, nervously waiting for Skype interviews or travelling across the country for assessment centres. As if the pressures of exams and assignments weren’t stressful enough, some of us have decided to add an extra strain by deciding to do a placement year – which means, well, finding a job. If you’re still looking, don’t give up. If you’re lucky enough to have secured a placement already, congrats – the next thing you need is a killer workwear wardrobe.

Dressing for a placement can seem a little daunting, especially if you’re used to turning up to lectures in leggings and a hoodie. But depending on your working environment, workwear can also be a great way to get creative with your personal style and put together looks that combine edge, elegance and professionalism. Whether you prefer to keep it simple, or dare to dress more fearlessly, make an impression wherever you’re working with some power dressing outfit inspiration.

THE SUIT

Nothing says strong, independent working woman like a suit. While secondary school and sixth form uniforms might spring to mind, the suit is a fashion favourite trend that returns season after season. Embracing all shapes, styles and colours, the suit is a versatile, go-to essential for any workwear wardrobe.

Pistachio suit, Topshop – Orange suit & Other Stories – Gingham suit, Zara

THE CLASSIC WHITE SHIRT

If there’s one thing you invest in for your placement year wardrobe, make it a white shirt. The most functional and adaptable workwear staple, a chic and crisp white shirt adds sophistication to any office outfit. Classics don’t have to be boring – go beyond with statement sleeves, ruffle detail or embroidery, or accessorise with splashes of colour.

Shirt with collar detail, Zara – Button-down shirt, Miss Selfridge – Belted shirt, Topshop

THE TURTLENECK

While we can all appreciate the allure of a power suit, it’s not the only way to achieve a chic and professional look for work. The turtleneck, the winter staple most of us probably already have in our wardrobes, is the perfect piece for achieving a smart-casual workwear look. Pair with a silk midi skirt or wide-leg trousers, or layer under dresses, blazers or jumpsuits for that dreamy comfort-meets-style feel.

Long-sleeve turtleneck T-shirt, Zara – Stone roll neck jumper, ASOS – Zebra print polo top, Warehouse 

THE TROUSERS

Whether you’re a fan of perfectly tailored cigarette trousers, or prefer a belted wide-leg pair, trousers are another versatile workwear essential. Experiment with statement prints and colours, or stay on trend for 2019 with beige and ivory hues.

Beige paper-bag wide-leg trousers, ASOS – Floral trousers, Mango – Black cigarette trousers, ASOS

THE SHOES

Shoes can elevate an outfit from play to work, but that doesn’t mean heels are your only option. From boots to flats, and mules to sling-backs, there’s a plethora of different footwear styles out there that’ll work wonderfully alongside any office apparel.

Black mules, Topshop – White boots, Mango – Leather flats, Zara

Text by Ruby McAuliffe

Picture research by Anna Irina; featured image from Pinterest.

The post The Workwear Edit – Placement Year Style Essentials appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: Discovering Your Personal Style
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
Defining personal style can be challenging as it means something different to everyone. In a broad sense, personal style is your taste and your preferences. It is expressing who you are and how you feel through what you wear; what music you listen to; how you style your hair and many other aspects of your […]

The post Discovering Your Personal Style appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Defining personal style can be challenging as it means something different to everyone. In a broad sense, personal style is your taste and your preferences. It is expressing who you are and how you feel through what you wear; what music you listen to; how you style your hair and many other aspects of your life. Your personal style says a lot about you! Personal style can encompass your entire personality and identity. It can be anything from which places you like to eat, to the way you carry yourself. To us, personal style is about feeling comfortable and confident in your own skin, and expressing your taste. 

Fashion is an amazing way to express your personal style. There are so many looks, trends and types of clothes to choose from that best suit you. The variety of choice can be overwhelming sometimes as it’s difficult to know what works for you. With this in mind, we have devised this top-tips guide on the best ways of finding your personal style.

  1. BE YOURSELF: It sounds obvious, but through the influence of social media, it is very easy to idolise and want to copy other people. Whilst social media, your friends and people in passing are fab sources of inspiration, reproducing other people’s styles on yourself may not always work for you. So, let your individuality shine through!
  2. INSPIRATION: Inspiration is all around us! A great way of discovering your personal style is by looking around and seeing what other styles you like or find inspirational. Nature can be a brilliant source of inspiration as the seasons and colours around us are always changing. Websites such as Pinterest also put together great mood boards for certain styles and looks. Additionally, your fellow students are a great source of inspiration! The diversity of student’s style on campus  is a great way of finding inspiration for different outfits and styles.
  3. EXPERIMENT: A simple way of learning what works for you and what doesn’t is through experimentation. There are a number of ways to experiment with different trends and styles in affordable ways. Firstly, get to know the thrift stores/charity shops and vintage stores in your local area. You can find some really great pieces at great prices if you spend time rummaging through the rails. You’ll often find that pieces and trends from decades passed can inspire your outfits. Secondly, there are loads of online sites that offer affordable second hand clothing. Some of our favourites are ASOSmarketplace, eBay and Depop. These sites can also give you a better idea of styles that appeal to you the most. Lastly, ask family members or friends if they have any fashion items they no longer want. Hand-me-downs are a great way of experimenting with style at no cost. (It’s also a fab way of grabbing one-off items).
  4. BUDGET: When buying new pieces on a budget, always think: is it practical?  And do I need it? It’s easy to impulse buy- we’ve all done it. But a student budget means impulse buying can lead to regrets. A top-tip is keeping a list of the items you need. Whether that be a warm coat for the colder winter months, or light t-shirts for summer. If you’re going to splurge on a statement item, make sure your budget can afford it
  5. BE OPEN TO CHANGE: Once you’ve found a style that makes you feel confident and comfortable, it’s easy to get stuck in a rut and become uninspired by your wardrobe, as putting together the same looks everyday can become tedious. Allow yourself to be inspired by new trends and new experiences.  A lot of leading magazines such as Vogue, Harper’s Bazaar, Cosmopolitan (and many more) publish Fashion Week recaps and new trend articles on their websites, which are free to access. Many high street stores also offer their interpretation of new trends in edits and look books online as well. Your style will evolve as you mature and grow. So, if you didn’t like wearing leopard print two years ago, you may feel differently towards it now.
  6. BE DARING: Don’t be afraid to wear something different and stand out from the crowd! Having the confidence to rock any look you want to is not always easy. But you have nothing to lose. What matters is if you feel your best, not what others think. Style is about expression so you might as well have fun and get creative!

Text by Natalie Carter

Picture research by Anna Irina, featured image from Pinterest.

The post Discovering Your Personal Style appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: Victoria’s Secret: The Road To Extinction?
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
Victoria’s Secret’s annual fashion show attracts billions of viewers across the globe every year. Undoubtedly, this makes the brand one of the world’s leading influencers in women’s fashion, especially lingerie. This being so, you would assume that Victoria’s Secret would be leading the way in the body diversity revolution. However, this is not the case. […]

The post Victoria’s Secret: The Road To Extinction? appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Victoria’s Secret’s annual fashion show attracts billions of viewers across the globe every year. Undoubtedly, this makes the brand one of the world’s leading influencers in women’s fashion, especially lingerie.

This being so, you would assume that Victoria’s Secret would be leading the way in the body diversity revolution. However, this is not the case. Despite consumers showing an increasing demand for brands to represent diversity in race, age and size across their catwalks, Victoria’s Secret models continue to represent the idealized female body, and not the real thing.

Vogue Magazine’s Nicole Phelps sat down with Ed Razek and Monica Mitro, the chief architects of the Victoria’s Secret 2018 fashion show. They discussed the brands evolution and their stance on the brands global message. The interview gave a shocking insight into the willfully blind and irresponsible attitude of two of the company’s most esteemed figures. The article covered topics such as plus-size inclusion in the industry and the backstage atmosphere at shows in relation to the #MeToo campaign. Here are some of our thoughts on the interview.

via standard.co.uk

The article begins with an overwhelmingly negative outlook on the Victoria’s Secret brand, with Phelps stating “as a social media–savvy generation” we expect to see ourselves “reflected in advertising and marketing; and, not least of all, a shift in the lingerie business itself. Maybe you’ve heard of Rihanna’s little project, Savage x Fenty?” This sets the tone for the rest of the article. When Rihanna launched her Savage x Fenty brand, she proved that any woman of any size, race and age can feel body confident in lingerie. The world watched as a truly diverse range of women walked the catwalk, reshaping the idea of what it is to ‘look good.’ However, in response to Rihanna’s show, Razek had this to say: “Everybody keeps talking about Rihanna’s show. If we had done Rihanna’s show, we would be accused of pandering without question… And all of these things that they’ve ‘invented,’ we have done and continue to do.” The blatant difference between the two shows being that Victoria’s Secret models are by no means plus size or diverse. Razek goes on to say: “We attempted to do a television special for plus-sizes [in 2000]. No one had any interest in it, still don’t.” On the contrary, the success of Rihanna’s Savage x Fenty show proves that the world is interested. We’re very interested.

 

As the article continues, the way both Razek and Mitro masterfully skirt around issues and avoid answering questions becomes tiresome and reveals a lot about how the company view their customers (in other words, they are happy to deceive them). In response to claims that Adrianna Lima (one of Victoria’s Secret’s longest serving ‘angels’) does not drink fluids up to a week before the show to achieve her athletic physique, Mitro gave the following response.

“This is her 18th year. She is 37 years old. She is so driven. And talk about age diversity. There aren’t a lot of brands that continue to use models past a certain age. But she’s an athlete; she boxes. That’s her routine, so if she’s with some nutritionist who says, “Try this, try that,” we don’t know.”

This calculated response implies Victoria’s Secret are not understanding the bigger picture. Their show has a direct effect on how both men and women view the female body and how ‘normal’ women, who aren’t VS models view their own bodies. There is nothing empowering about a scantily clad, skeletally thin woman blowing kisses as she walks down a runway. Rather, that image is something ‘normal’ women will never achieve.

© Josh Wong Photography

In addition, in response to Victoria’s Secret 2018 show, Vanessa Freidman for The New York Times had this to say: “to think that presenting women as presents to be unwrapped does not shape social expectations is to fool yourself.” Freidman suggests it is expected that this type of sexualized voyeurism is detrimental to the female image, and the orchestrators of the Victoria’s secret brand know it, yet they refuse to take responsibility. Instead, as Razek declares in his interview with Vogue “the show is a fantasy. It’s a 42-minute entertainment special. That’s what it is. It is the only one of its kind in the world.” It is no wonder then, when a global brand is intent on creating a “fantasy” world for its consumers that completely unrealistic expectations of the female body are created.

 

Vogue’s article proves to us that Victoria’s Secret is a brand completely out of touch with what modern consumers want. When a brand is “really proud” of allowing their models to “wear their natural hair” on the runway, it shows the extent of the modifications that Victoria’s Secret impose upon their own models. It is unsurprising then, given the brand’s unrealistic expectations on the female image, that Victoria’s Secret continue to perpetuate “an idea of sexy rooted in the pinup era, when women and their bodies were defined by the eye and imagination of a male beholder” but, crucially as Freidman claims “that era is on its way to extinction.” It would appear however, that Victoria’s Secret’s indifferent attitude to what their consumers want is coming at a cost. With their market share and sales figures falling over recent years, how long will their age of ignorance continue?

 

References

Freidman, V (2018) ‘Victoria’s Secret Is Trying to Change With the Times. Or Is It?’ The New York Times (New York Edition), 9 November. Accessed at: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/09/fashion/victorias-secret-liberation-in-corsets-and-spike-heels.html

Phelps, N (2018) ‘“We’re Nobody’s Third Love, We’re Their First Love”—The Architects of the Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show Are Still Banking on Bombshells,’ Vogue Magazine (Runway Edition), 8 November. Accessed at: https://www.vogue.com/article/victorias-secret-ed-razek-monica-mitro-interview

 

Text by Natalie Carter

Picture research by Anna Irina, featured image from Pinterest. 

The post Victoria’s Secret: The Road To Extinction? appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: SUBCULTURED X CHEAP MONDAY
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
There are few items in the student wardrobe that can claim they have seen said student through everything, from running around campus during the day to the early morning hours looking for food after a good night out. Jeans would definitely be included in that list. And so the mission is simple: the cooler the […]

The post SUBCULTURED X CHEAP MONDAY appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
There are few items in the student wardrobe that can claim they have seen said student through everything, from running around campus during the day to the early morning hours looking for food after a good night out. Jeans would definitely be included in that list. And so the mission is simple: the cooler the pair of jeans is, the more versatile the styling. Add to that good quality, and you truly have an item that can see you through every hour of your busy student life.

Cheap Monday zeroed in on the importance of good denim and has made a huge mark in the fashion market with its line: clothes that are comfortable, whether loose-fitting or figure-hugging, with an original design that makes a statement effortlessly. Whether it is a pop of neon orange in an all-black outfit, a skull necklace or a logo-bearing pair of jeans, the result is the same: a look that combines functional urban cool – in other words, comfort with a bit of an edge and lots of attitude. Against the backdrop of busy London, with its graffitied alleyways and iconic buildings, the clothes stand out among the crowds due to their vibrant, rebellious feel.

I suppose, then, there is only one thing left to say: thank God, it’s… (Cheap) Monday.

 Orange Jumper – Tap Echologo Knit

Black Sweater – Worth Droop Logo Sweat

Women’s Ripped Jeans – Dona Slash Black Mom Jeans

Men’s Orange Hoodie – Scope Fleece Hood

Orange T-shirt – Screen Tiny Skull Tee

Red Coat – Agent Bomber

Women’s Jeans with Side Panelling – Sound 36 Black Tape Jeans

Grey Beanie – Skull Beanie

Quilted Jacket – Crypto Puffer Vest

Men’s Jeans – Tight Horror Skinny Jeans

Women’s Fleece Jacket – Function Fleece Jacket

Denim Jacket – Legit Denim Jacket

 

A peek at the behind-the-scenes of the shoot:

 

Creative direction by Rebecca Cofie, Setareh Sanjarani and Natalie Carter

Photography by Leeya Mirza

Videography by Ana Maria

Editorial by Alice Papadopoulou

Models: Kyle Birkitt, Mack McCarroll, Talia Cherkez & Silia Marianou

Special thanks to Cheap Monday for collaborating with us.

The post SUBCULTURED X CHEAP MONDAY appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
